The Marching Minutemen keeping it classy!

From Adam Loudin...
The LCHS Band only had a few hours to rehearse this week in preparation for tonight’s game against Elkins.

Allen Heath chose to spend some of that time teaching the Elkins High School fight song to the band. The game was supposed to be a home game for Elkins and had to be played at Lewis County due to safety issues with Elkins’ facility. Mr. Heath felt the Elkins team deserved to hear their fight song played and I couldn’t agree more.

A true display of class and sportsmanship. Bravo!

Lewis County High School
From Lesley White-
Here is the snapshot of what school will look like upon re-entry from a student's perspective. Of course, guidelines will change as we navigate this uncharted territory. Please know that school officials are still working out logistics, and policies are fluid with the ever-changing COVID situation.

Please be patient with all of us. There will be questions. Some that can be answered; some that may not have an absolute answer. There will be changes, modifications, and adjustments.

However, what you must remember, is that we are all doing our best during the biggest educational crisis of our lifetime.

Many thanks to all who made this video possible. A big thanks to Mr. Whiston, Vincent Snuffer, Lily Garton, Allison McWhorter, Brian Fisher, and Dustin Cogar. And, as with most things, there are lots of behind-the-scenes-people who keep us all afloat. Many thanks to all who have worked tirelessly to give our students the best and safest education possible.

#MinutemenStrong #LewisReady

Today in West Virginia, many places still don’t have good connectivity, broadband, even cell service. This problem is especially urgent right now as students rely on broadband access to continue their schoolwork during the coronavirus pandemic. That’s why Federal Communications Commission Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel and I are partnering with the students and faculty at Lewis County High School to bring attention to the lack of high-speed broadband internet in rural West Virginia.

We visited Lewis County High School in October to discuss broadband access, and the importance of conducting speed tests in order to create accurate coverage maps for rural states like West Virginia. Three Little Pigs Unit:
This week we studied the different variations of Three Little Pigs! In The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs we had the chance to listen to Mr. Wolf’s side of the story. The kids and I still think that his story isn’t the truth. We then read the story The Three Little Wolves and the Big Bar Pig! The kids definitely found this to be their favorite variation. We used the Double Bubble Map to compare and contrast this story with the original Three Little Pigs ! Our last variation of the Three Little Pigs was the story Three Ninja Pigs! Throughout the week our kids worked through several stations in which they had to use their creativity and knowledge of the story to complete the activity. Our students designed houses on paper to keep the big bad wolf out! We used the Fairy Tale STEM kits to build a house for our 3 little pigs and today they built houses out of DOTS, marshmallow and toothpicks! Another successful unit packed full of learning, fun and creativity!
